ygData.subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Jeff, ... Correct, I wouldn t insist on a quantitative measure in that case. However, as I said before, what does saying they are [interestingly]

From: "rhiever489" <rhiever@...>
Subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=550414109; y=TrgCZ0clyxPYrboSXtoAEVh6SL1BRrZAKbC7a6ScY_lexY5BLdirBCb5KXEkAl3GZTKj3flfF-Aix4Q
X-Yahoo-Profile: rhiever489

Hey Jeff,

> We could have an interesting conversation about these observat=
ion, and someone could even defend that L-systems are more natural (e.g. th=
ey better resemble plants), but it's not the case that that conversation wo=
uld be better had with numbers, or would be best settled by a quantitative =
metric. The point is that until we invent true AI with similar pattern-reco=
gnition to humans, we don't have the ability to quantify the recognition of=
 interestingly different types of patterns even though those differences ar=
e obvious to humans. This is the same reason why "monet-ness" is pretty cle=
ar to us when we see it, but we can't quantify it well/easily. I should poi=
nt out that I'm not saying that phenomena like "monet-ness" are not quantif=
iable in principle=85.eventually we will invent AI that can "see" the world=
 and recognize high-dimnsional clusters (like "monet-ness" and "pollack-nes=
s" as different things, as well as quantify "naturalness") and at that poin=
t we probably can quantify these traits, but at present we can't do that in=
 a way that is ultimately helpful. If you are a reviewer and you force some=
one to try to quantify properties like "naturalness", "monet-ness", etc., y=
ou are making things worse only in the name of claiming it's objective beca=
use it is quantitative. Your brain is simply better at some things than our=
 algorithms, and for those domains we should use our brains to evaluate the=
 results, not numbers. Doing so doesn't make the statements "hollow", unint=
eresting, or unscientific. You will of course object that they are "subject=
ive" judgements, and they are, but they are the best we've got and they can=
 still be helpful. I will agree (in line with JBM) that we should only acce=
pt such results when they are "obvious to us", so maybe the claim "CPPNs ar=
e more natural than L-Systems" should be curbed by a reviewer, but somethin=
g as obvious as "they are different" should not. 

> Do you still agree wit=
h this statement after my above examples? Surely you agree that Jackson Pol=
lack paints in a different style than Monet, but I'm guessing you also woul=
dn't insist on a quantitative measure before making that claim in a scienti=
fic publication. If you would insist on that, then I think you are forgetti=
ng that quantitative measures are supposed to be tools that help advance sc=
ientific progress, not chains that should bind us and slow us down. 

Corre=
ct, I wouldn't insist on a quantitative measure in that case. However, as I=
 said before, what does saying "they are [interestingly] different" tell us=
? How can we take that statement and build off of it, other than saying tha=
t we made something else that looks interestingly different? I could have a=
 program use a random number generator to make some random art and some of =
those art pieces would be interestingly different as well. What does that t=
ell us about the process underlying it? Like you said, we can't claim that =
any method produces more "natural" or more "monet-y" designs with a qualita=
tive analysis, so can we really say anything substantial that someone could=
 take and advance the field with?

I think that's a major concern to addres=
s: Can we make any substantial claims with a qualitative analysis?


> By t=
hat rationale you don't think the Picbreeder paper should have been publish=
ed, or Karl Sims work, is that right? The Picbreeder papers collectively ha=
ve over 100 citations, and Sims' work arguably kickstarted/inspired the ent=
ire field of artificial life and has thousands of citations. Picbreeder als=
o visually demonstrates the power of CPPNs, provides an intuitive testbed f=
or learning how they work, but also taught us lessons about Evolutionary Co=
mputation in general; the entire idea for novelty search emerged as a resul=
t of the Picbreeder system! If your attitudes for what merits a publication=
 were universal, no one would pursue this type of work because of the low v=
alue you place on it would mean that doing so would not help one's career, =
and thus such important work would not be done. I don't really get why we w=
ould want to eliminate such valuable work. So much crap gets published just=
 because it has a few quantitative comparisons: I think we can spare a few =
paper slots for work that is interesting, yet not quantifiable. 

I'm not s=
ure if cherrypicking a few success cases out of far more failures proves th=
e point. I won't say that all proof of concept work is not worth publishing=
 (obviously some is), and it's nearly impossible to judge the impact work w=
ill have in the long term. However, it is fair to assume that work that tea=
ches us something new about the world (see the examples I listed before, e.=
g., Bongard 2011) is more likely to have a lasting impact than a proof of c=
oncept in a particular system.

The most straightforward way to learn somet=
hing about a phenomenon is to measure it. That way, the argument over the r=
esults immediately goes to an objective discussion ("what is the proper way=
 to measure this?") rather than subjective ("well, I think this looks more =
Monet-y..."). Science progresses most expediently by discussing how we can =
measure and reproduce phenomena, rather than waving our hands and talking f=
rom a subjective standpoint.


> This comment reveals that we did fail to c=
ommunicate the technique, because with the Seeded-CPPN technique CPPNs are =
not trained in any way. It's possible that this misunderstanding contribute=
s to your belief that the Seeded-CPPN technique should be compared to targe=
t-based evolution, because if we were indeed were *training* CPPNs to repro=
duce an object then it would be more reasonable to require a comparison to =
alternate methods of training them to reproduce the same object (i.e. targe=
t-based evolution). Note: the technique does allow for *further* evolution =
of an arbitrary shape=85so evolutionary "training" does occur, but only aft=
er starting from the seed shape. 
> 
> With the Seeded-CPPN technique, you =
don't train the CPPN: you inject the geometry of the seed object into the C=
PPN via the ds (distanceToSurface) input. For each voxel, that ds input con=
veys the distance between that voxel and the surface of the surface (outer =
shell) of the target object (along with a sign indicating if that voxel is =
inside or outside the object). A CPPN recreates the shape by filling in all=
 voxels inside the shape, but the technique also allows for warping of the =
object. For example, for a CPPN to increase the size of the target output s=
imilarly in all dimensions, it could find all voxels that are x centimeters=
 away from, and outside of, the target object and fill them (and everything=
 inside of them) in." For a CPPN to increase the width, but not the height,=
 of an object, it could fill in the original object plus any voxels x cm aw=
ay in the width-dimension, etc. Or it could do more complicated things base=
d on the shape's geometry. Thus the CPPN can immediately start from a desir=
ed pattern (in this case the shape of the object) and then elaborate on tha=
t shape by adding/subtracting from the original design, or by warping the o=
riginal design. 

Aha, I get it now. And yes -- I would also now agree that=
 making a comparison to targeted evolution would not be valuable at that po=
int, since you are not training the CPPN to reproduce the shape at all. Ind=
eed, as Ken said, your message here is that you can seed a CPPN in such a w=
ay then evolve it into other objects -- objects that either look similar an=
d that look completely dissimilar.

That said, a qualitative analysis may n=
ot thoroughly prove your point. You've shown that the Seeded-CPPNs can evol=
ve into slightly morphed or completely dissimilar shapes in a few instances=
, but what happens over hundreds of instances? Is morphing into a completel=
y dissimilar shape an extremely rare event, or is it common? What about sli=
ghtly morphed shapes? Or are a large portion of the mutations neutral? What=
ever the answer to these questions, what would the implications of those an=
swers be for someone who wanted to use Seeded-CPPNs?

Now that I understand=
 your paper better, there are many unanswered questions that would be impor=
tant for me to know if I wanted to use the Seeded-CPPN technique, and I'm f=
airly sure only a quantitative analysis could answer them.


Cheers,
Randy
=
